wayneJ Quote: 'The second is that the same two schools rowed for the right to wear pink (after the Leander Club). Eton lost, Westminster chose pink and Eton, light blue.' - source - https://www.newandlingwood.com/the-editorial/post/the-history-of-eton-blue/

BE11:30am

Zalando announced on April 15, 2019 that it expects 1Q19 adjusted EBIT to come in at “positive single-digit“ millions [GSe -€0.1mn, company compiled consensus -€10mn]. GMV growth (company compiled consensus of 23%) and revenue growth [GSe 14%, company compiled consensus 15.2%] is expected to be in line with market expectations.

JuB comment # 85
wayneJ @Tom - my biggest worry would be if a 10% commission to BE for promoting the idea internally would mean he might smile???
BE11:32am

The difference between GMV and revenues could reflect a higher contribution from brands {including higher discounting} as well as accounting difference between GMV vs revenue recognition.

BE11:32am

We would highlight that 1Q generally has limited contribution towards full-year profitability.

FY19 guidance: Zalando highlighted that the results are “in-line with the company’s full-year outlook“. Full year guidance for FY19 is: revenue growth at the low end range of 20-25%, GMV growth of 20-25% and adjusted EBIT between €175-225mn. Zalando expects FY19 capex of €300mn.

What does is all mean? All else equal, we expect company compiled consensus for full year adj. EBIT to increase by 2%-3% to c.€200m (+15% yoy), taking into account the beat in 1Q19 and seasonality.
Valuation: Our 12-month PT of €35 is DCF derived [WACC of 9% and terminal growth rate of 2%]. Our rating is Neutral. Zalando trades on 1.28x CY19E EV/sales and 59x EV/EBIT.

Brutto @Blank Canvas - is that because Wil E Coyote has been buying..?
nightingale20201 morning all
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Which is important. It's largely a model change from direct to marketplace.

Pharma I remember when ML *first* reached 100 comments. Sometime back when the great financial crash was getting warmed up (2008?). Gosh, that's a long time ago.Now Bryce gets sad with <100 comments, and zero news.
wayneJ I note Izzy on Twitter saying AI Bots confused Notre Dame stories last night with Twin Towers / 911 stories - not good for AI....
Soundbuy Discoverie Grp - if you're scrabbling around later.............any grey
BE11:33am

Though it's not a warning, and that in itself is positive given history.

BE11:33am

Barclays.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

The details: in Q1 they expect GMV and revenue growth to be broadly in line with company consensus (currently 23% and 15% respectively with Barclays at 23% and 17%). They had already been clear at the CMD in early March that there would be a wide gap between GMV and revenues in this quarter as the shift to the Partner Program (marketplaces) has accelerated during Q1 – we strongly believe the key metric is now GMV and not revenues. Our conversations with the buyside suggest this was well understood. The concern on the buyside had been the profitability implications of this shift (which seems to be dilutive for the time being). However, they expect positive adjusted EBIT “in the single digit millions”, ahead of consensus of -€10m (Barclays has -€14m). This implies that Q1 is c€15m better than consensus – so this certainly isn’t a dramatic deviation from expectations but slightly better. They haven’t given any more breakdown by geography or cost item – we will get that with the full Q1 results on May 2.

Of course Q1 is a very small quarter for overall annual profitability, so we will get a better sense of how realistic the FY guidance is when Q2 is completed (a much bigger quarter). They haven’t changed the FY guidance of €175-225m. But it is positive that they have successfully cleared the first hurdle set at their CMD. Putting this alongside a confident message given at the CMD, and with comps now getting easier into Q2 and Q3 (revenues grew 21% in Q2 2018 and 12% in Q3 2018), to us it feels like the chances of delivering on forecasts through this year is increasing. And this is a story that is now all about delivery – as we outlined in “Shifting focus back to the long term” (March 6 2019), there is still ample flex in the Zalando valuation to be fundamentally positive here, with lots of optionality as they shift to marketplaces and start to monetise with advertising (the market continues to price a very low 1P margin in outer years). But valuation is nothing without momentum in the world of ecommerce, so earnings delivery this year would certainly help.

We would continue to be buying the stock here and reiterate our Overweight rating.

The Q1 EBIT beat is the second meaningful beat vs consensus in a row (Q4 was well ahead too) and comes after the group’s (in our view) conservative FY19 guidance and positive strategic update at the CMD in Feb. with bullish mid/long term targets discussed in detail in On the way to a higher margin/lower risk business model. We reiterate our Outperform rating.

BE11:39am

Here's UBS.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

FY19 adjusted EBITDA £89.4mFY EBITDA was within £89-91m guidance (UBSe £89m). Sales had already been given for 11 months including peak, so no surprise with LFL -0.1%. Gross margin was better than expected, with more mitigation than planned from supply chain efficiencies and possibly mix. Against this, cost pressures including wages and utilities weighed, partially offset by ongoing efficiency plans. The interest charge was c£1m higher than expected with a c9% increase in average debt levels and an increase in average funding costs (LIBOR and debt ratchets). The ordinary dividend was maintained at 9.3p

BE11:39am

Management is satisfied with the start to the year and is particularly pleased with sales over Valentine's Day and Mother's Day. However, EBITDA guidance is unchanged, likely reflecting the early stage of the year and potentially some benefit against weather-affected comps. With the hedged FX rate level, gross margin should follow suit, although some opex pressures will remain. We assume some recovery in FY LFL (+0.5%) driven by product development and availability. UBS FY20E EPS falls 1.5% with a higher interest charge. We expect another special dividend to be made towards the end of the financial year; UBSe is 7.5p (FY19 5.0p)

BE11:39am

The latest OC&C card market survey sees no change – modest volume decline, modest value growth, and with Card Factory maintaining its strong competitive position. However, with space contribution slowing as CF moves towards its 1200 target, there are plans to drive growth from other areas. 1) Card Factory online will see additional investment, as customer awareness is low. Click & collect will be enabled this year. 2) Trials continue to supply third party retailers. Aldi has moved from a dozen stores to 112, although it is still in trial mode. 3) Vertical integration is set to increase, with additional investment in added value cards and further automation. FX movements since the Brexit vote are partly behind this. Against this, Getting Personal sales remain weak.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Our PT is based on DCF. We assume 1.5% TRG, 15% terminal margin (FY19 18%) and 8.2% WACC (all unchanged).

Here's Bruno.

BE11:52am

With the good news out of the way, what comes in front looks like a torrent of bad catalysts:

(1) A material price cut on daily essentials, but without the Asda merger to fund it

(2) Formal end to the Asda merger, pushing the question: 'what now for the strategy?'

(3) Argos margins will remain weak as retailers keep going bust

(4) The bank remains a cash drain through 'integration costs', 'capital injection' and 'capex'

(5) Kantar 4-weekly data points likely to remain weak and bottom of the big-4

(6) New discounter space impacts SBRY more than others, as discounters come South

(7) IFRS 16 is likely to impact SBRY more than others

As if that wasn't enough, investors are starting to wonder whether the new chairman may want to change the CEO (unjustified but not impossible) and whether the quality of SBRY's earnings are as solid as its peers. This is an ugly backdrop for the company. We cut EPS by 8%-9%.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The initial findings from a review of the Construction division has pointed to further exceptional costs of £30-40m. Further details about the future shape and scale of the division should be forthcoming with the 21 May trading update. In the meantime we have factored in a negative value for the Construction division given the increased uncertainty and performance of the business. As a result our Sum of the Parts value drops to 700p. We lower our recommendation to Hold until more details are revealed.

wayneJ And the family has some interesting background..... plus u are exchanging above or below the gross profit line costs ......eg the cost of the vending machine and the 'technology' investments.....
BE11:55am

Forecasts & Recommendation: While our underlying PBT does not change, we will assume that £40m worth of exceptionals are charged this year against reported PBT. Given the continued uncertainty about the performance, size and future of the Construction business we now factor in a negative value of c110p per share. This takes into account possible further disappointments from the Aberdeen road, other meaningful contracts, costs to downsize and the loss of some upfront cash payments. This leads us to cut our TP to 700p and we move our recommendation to Hold, we will review this position when more details come out in May.

Irish HF guy @wayne J, of course. CarMax is the largest used car dealer. they seem to make $2k per car, both Carvana and CarMax and more when they finance it.. the usual story, its the extras which somehow make some business models work.
BE11:56am

And Canaccord too.

wayneJ @BornCynic - major 2nd hand car sellers will give 24hrs to 7 day returns if u ask.
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Clearly the detail and magnitude of the anticipated costs have yet to be finalised and average net debt for the next financial year looks likely to be higher than current expectations, despite staying the same for the current financial year. It is also disappointing to see this warning so soon after management had essentially reiterated its confidence in the full year expectations at the time of its interim results reported in February. Valuation looks tempting but the lack of visibility and uncertainty around estimates (earnings and net debt beyond the current financial year) is not reassuring and we expect the shares to move sharply lower today. Dividend yields in the wider UK housebuilding sector look as attractive for selective names with much better visibility and confidence in them being delivered.

BE11:56am

The shares reside on a FY2020E PE and EV:EBITDA multiple of c.5 times and c.4.5 times respectively, and offer offer a dividend yield of around 10%.

current trading year to date. With its strong brand relationships and high calibre
team, we see competitors lagging behind, as the recent acquisition of Footasylum
confirms, and JD being particularly well positioned. Buy rating reiterated.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Slight beat to consensus. We expect the share price today to respond positively to the
company's full-year results: FY19 sales £4,717.8m, +49%, 3.4% better than expectations
(consensus £4,562m, +44%), driven by the Sports Fashion business (with a surprising
6% LFL in the sports fascia). Underlying PBT £355.2m, c.2% higher than expected
(consensus £349m). Net cash £125.m. Dividend 1.71p.
Update on Finish Line, Outdoor and Brexit. JD's trial in the US is delivering
encouraging early results; Outdoor, despite having a challenging year due to
unseasonable weather, delivered double-digit EBITDA. Management recognises the
uncertainty surrounding Brexit (namely the potential consequences on supply chains,
tariffs, exchange rates and consumer demand), but remains confident in the international
potential of the JD proposition.
Footasylum acquisition, the latest proof of strength. On Friday 12 April, JD made
an unconditional offer on Footasylum for a price consideration of a c.£90m. The price
represents a c.67% discount to the valuation at its peak. We believe Footasylum
represents a good fit to JD as both businesses occupy the premium sports fascia, with
Footasylum targeting slightly older customer groups compared to JD, leveraging a bigger
wholesale business (c.10% of revenues vs JD 1%) and online participation (30% of
revenues are online vs JD 18%). We do not anticipate store closures or store fascia
rebranding for the first 12 months, nor after, as long as stores are profitable.
JD stock up 65% over the past four months. The stock trades at 17x P/E, a 10%
discount to the 2019 Cal. Sector P/E (incl. of ASOS and boohoo). We like the shares
as management continues to impress with its metrics-driven and demanding approach
to sports retailing. With its strong brand relationships and high calibre team, we see
competitors as miles behind and JD being particularly well positioned. Resistance to
follow the herd, a clinical approach to strategy and a clear understanding of the retail
environment: these are the elements that make us comfortable with our Buy rating.
